creator.name: Joe Brewer
creator.bio: I am a change strategist working on behalf of humanity, and also a complexity researcher, cognitive scientist, and evangelist for the field of culture design.

paragraphs.name: cfa2
paragraphs.text: Explaining Police Violence with Cultural Evolution

paragraphs.name: 57ab
paragraphs.text: What are the cultural factors giving rise to police violence?

paragraphs.name: 6ee9
paragraphs.text: This week there has been yet-another shooting of an innocent black man by a white police officer. I would like to take a moment and share one of the things I’ve learned from studying cultural evolution that might be helpful here.

paragraphs.name: 431c
paragraphs.text: There is a large body of research on “cultural transmission” — where information is learned socially in ways that perpetuate or evolve the social practices for a given community. Among the findings from this research are several biases or tendencies that show how learning occurs in ways that prove to be adaptive for the community.

paragraphs.name: 9a7e
paragraphs.text: One of these is prestige bias, which means people tend to imitate the actions of others who are recognized for their skill or expertise. Another is conformity bias, whereby people imitate what is most commonly done (When in Rome, do as the Romans do…) since it is likely to be useful and effective. Through these learning strategies people adopt behaviors that help them navigate the complexities of their social worlds.

What does this have to do with the man who was killed in Tulsa this week? Simply put, there has been a long history of media representation (think of the 90’s show “Cops”) that culturally transmitted the idea that large-framed black men are scary, dangerous, and likely to be aggressive. This social learning (incorrect though it is) has led to a widespread fear of large black men by white people — including white people who become trained in the use of firearms who then enroll to become police officers.

paragraphs.name: 7d78
paragraphs.text: A combination of prestige bias in popular films showing highly skilled military personnel and police officers who shoot and kill dark-skinned villains and the prevalence of biased depictions in the media (conformity bias) has significantly shaped the emotional sensibilities of people who now are in positions to use lethal force.

paragraphs.name: 875f
paragraphs.text: We can learn much from this situation. The one thing I hope this little teach-in on cultural evolutionary studies can offer is that much can be brought from the social and biological sciences to help us improve our media practices, how we train our police officers, and what can be done to evolve the social norms and behaviors of people throughout our society.

paragraphs.name: 1d80
paragraphs.text: We can apply the strategies of prestige and conformity bias to reduce the likelihood that terrible things like this happen in the future.
